awd_titl_txt: Nanomanufacturing of Protein Macromolecular Frameworks Through an Integrated Bioengineering and Computational Approach
awd_abstract_narration:
New materials with innovative functionalities are needed to build new and useful devices and systems that enrich our lives. Ordered three-dimensional arrays built from nanoscale building-blocks, often called superlattices, are exciting because new functionalities can emerge from the interactions between individual building-blocks. The use of proteins as building-blocks is a groundbreaking new direction because proteins exhibit a wide range of properties and behavior, including catalytic and immune activities, which are often difficult to realize in synthetic molecules. Making ordered materials by conventional protein crystallization is a laborious procedure and the ability to tailor the structure of protein crystals is limited. This award supports fundamental research to develop versatile and tunable approaches to manufacture superlattice materials constructed of proteins. The availability of these unique protein-based materials impacts diverse industries such as energy, biomedical and catalysis, which advances national welfare. This project uniquely integrates several disciplines including materials science, bioengineering and computational modeling. The integration of experimental and computational approaches in this project impacts research efforts of the Network for Computational Nanotechnology (NCN), synergistically. Alongside the scientific impact of the project, it also leverages the multi-disciplinary approach to promote students, including women and minorities, on this project by acquiring broad skills and knowledge and by providing a positive impact on science education.

The research team envisions that protein cage nanoparticles and linker proteins, which bind non-covalently to symmetry-specific sites on the protein cages, are promising building-blocks for constructing a new class of protein superlattices, i.e. protein macromolecular frameworks. Protein cages have hollow spherical architectures composed of a distinct number of subunits with well-defined symmetry-specific sites. The investigators anticipate that specific binding geometries between protein cages and linkers result in highly regular network structures with a wide range of functionalities. The research team integrates bioengineering and computational modeling approaches to develop a range of linker molecules with different lengths and binding affinities to protein cages. By connecting the protein cages together through protein linkers, they are geometrically confined, thus forming highly regulated structures. The structure of the protein macromolecular frameworks is tunable through the selection of protein cages and specific linker proteins. Additionally, protein macromolecular frameworks have two types of unique spaces internally to accommodate cargo molecules. These are interior cavity of individual protein cages and interstitial space between protein cages within the lattice. The team demonstrates that various cargo molecules, such as enzymes, could be encapsulated inside of the protein cages. In this project, reversible incorporation and release of guest molecules are studied, which could lead protein macromolecular frameworks to practical applications such as drug delivery and catalysis.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcome

Introduction

This NSF-funded project focused on the development of protein-based three-dimensional (3D) array materials with tunable properties and hierarchical organization. By integrating computational protein design, bioengineering, and materials science, this work has led to significant advancements in the field of protein framework materials. These achievements have both scientific and technological implications, including the development of novel protein-based materials for applications such as catalysis. Additionally, this project has provided extensive research training and educational opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students, significantly contributing to workforce development in STEM fields.

Intellectual Merit

This project successfully advanced the field of protein-based materials by achieving several key milestones including:

1.     Development of a Machine Learning Approach for Protein Docking Model Selection

2.     Computationally Guided Protein Linker Design

3.     Establishment of a Strategy for Hierarchical Assembly of 3D Protein Arrays

4.     Design and Characterization of Core-Shell Superlattices

5.     Stimuli-Responsive Reversible Assembly of Protein Building Blocks

6.     Encapsulation of Gold Nanoparticles Using Self-Assembling Protein Capsids


These achievements represent significant contributions to the fields of computational protein modeling, protein engineering, and protein-based nanomaterials manufacturing. The successful integration of experimental and computational approaches has expanded the capabilities of protein-based material design, setting the stage for future advancements in this emerging field.

Broader Impacts

Beyond scientific contributions, this project has had a substantial impact on education, workforce development, and the broader scientific community. Key broader impacts include:

 

1.     Dissemination of Research Findings
This project led to the publication of over eleven research articles in high-impact, peer-reviewed journals.

2.     Training and Mentorship of Students and Researchers
A total of ten undergraduate students, eight graduate students, one postdoctoral researcher, one post-master’s researcher, and one post-bachelor’s researcher received research training through this NSF-funded project.

3.     Conference Presentations and Professional Development
Nearly all undergraduate and graduate students who participated in this research had opportunities to present their findings at scientific conferences.

4.     Authorship and Contributions to Scientific Literature
Most graduate students involved in this project were co-authors of published research articles.

5.     Hands-On Training at Argonne National Laboratory and UC Merced
Many students involved in this project received training in small-angle X-ray scattering (SAXS) at Argonne National Laboratory and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) at UC Merced.

6.     Interdisciplinary Collaboration and Integration of Research into Education
This project uniquely integrated nanomaterials science, bioengineering, and computational protein modeling. Through collaboration with computational scientists, students gained exposure to advanced modeling techniques.

Conclusion

This NSF-funded research has significantly advanced the ability to design and construct protein-based materials with tunable properties. The combination of computational and experimental approaches enabled the development of novel protein framework materials with applications in biotechnology, nanotechnology, and materials science. The findings from this work have been widely disseminated through high-impact publications and conference presentations, providing valuable contributions to the scientific community.

Moreover, this project has had a profound impact on education and workforce development, training numerous undergraduate and graduate students, postdoctoral researchers, and early-career scientists. By integrating research with education and fostering interdisciplinary collaboration, this work has prepared the next generation of researchers to tackle complex challenges in protein materials science.

The outcomes of this award lay the foundation for future innovations in manufacturing protein-based nanomaterials. Continued exploration of computationally guided protein design and hierarchical assembly strategies will further expand the capabilities of protein materials, unlocking new possibilities for their applications in energy, medicine, and environmental science.


Last Modified: 01/29/2025
Modified by: Masaki Uchida
